awd_titl_txt: SaTC: CORE: Small: Secure Cloud Storage Verification Methods
awd_abstract_narration:
With the continuously decreasing costs of cloud services, many organizations including government agencies, healthcare providers, financial institutions, universities, and enterprises outsource large data repositories to cloud service providers (CSPs). Doing this relieves organizations from the financial burden of deploying and maintaining in-house data infrastructures. However, storing data with third parties exposes organizations to legal and financial liabilities should the data leak, become unavailable, or be lost. To reduce these risks, CSPs employ reliable storage technologies which are outlined in service level agreements (SLAs) negotiated with their clients. An SLA states data availability/reliability guarantees against misconfigurations, attacks, and any other disruption. Current SLAs, however, do not specify mechanisms for verifying that the CSP is adhering to the SLA terms. Accidental misconfigurations or attacks can lead to irrecoverable data loss that is detected only long after it has occurred. Moreover, economically motivated CSPs may choose to circumvent the SLA to reduce their operational costs. This project aims to design and test auditing mechanisms for provably and efficiently verifying adherence to SLA terms. The effort is well-aligned with national priorities on critical infrastructure security and resilience. It will result in cloud architectures, storage algorithms, and network and security protocols that strengthen the security, privacy, and usability of cloud storage systems, advancing the state-of-the-art on reliable and secure data storage. The project team will also use the work to inform the development of related courses and a cybersecurity certificate program, as well as supporting outreach efforts to middle and high school students and to groups traditionally underrepresented in computer science.

The research agenda is organized around two major activities. The first activity investigates storage verification methods that not only prove the existence of the outsourced data but also verify the storage of redundant information for recovering from attacks and failures. Achieving such high levels of assurance is challenging because redundant information can be easily regenerated on-the-fly whenever the CSP is challenged to prove its existence. Effective auditing mechanisms require the joint design of the verification, coding, and data recovery processes to optimize the security-reliability-resource-efficiency tradeoffs while preserving data privacy and supporting data updatability. The second activity explores the physical storage verification at multiple storage nodes within a data center and/or between data centers.  The team approaches the physical storage and geodiversity verification problems from the realistic standpoint of utilizing bounds on the physical resources such as network delay (which can be set conservatively). This allows technology-agnostic storage verification methods that are future-proof. A core project goal is the integration of logical and physical storage verification methods under a single suite of protocols. This integration is jointly considered with practical operational aspects of cloud systems, including data maintenance, dynamic data update, and privacy preservation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Cloud service providers (CSPs) promise a high degree of availability, security, and reliability for any data stored in the cloud. Performance and security guarantees are reflected in Service Level Agreements (SLAs) which are contractually established between CSPs and their clients. However,  data is subjected to Byzantine failures, misconfigurations, and many attack vectors that can lead to irrecoverable data corruption or leakage to unauthorized parties. Despite the risk of data loss, clients do not have mechanisms for verifying the CSP's adherence to the SLA terms. In many situations, data loss is discovered when clients try to access their data which leaves them with little recourse for data recovery. 

This project aimed at developing novel methods for the remote verification of the security, reliability, and privacy guarantees stipulated in the SLA terms.  Specifically, the PIs developed new cloud storage audit protocols referred to as "Proofs of Reliability (PoRLs)" which implement communication-efficient proofs about file retrievability but also file repairability (i.e., the ability of the CSP to reconstruct partially corrupted files from redundant storage). The key challenge addressed by PoRLs is verifying the storage of redundant file blocks (parities) despite the CSP's ability to reconstruct such blocks on the fly from the original data. The PIs proposed interactive probabilistic PoRLs relying on locally-repairable codes which are commonly employed in data centers to reduce the network overhead for file repair. The PIs further investigated the integration of storage verification with practical operational aspects of cloud systems, including data maintenance, dynamic data update, and privacy preservation. The developed methods jointly design storage verification, error correction, and data recovery to optimize relevant tradeoffs. 

Moreover, storage reliability assurances were extended from the logical level (existence of redundant data) to the physical level where the goal is to verify that file blocks are distributed across multiple physical storage devices. The PIs developed new physical challenge-response protocols that utilize time bounds on data retrievability to verify storage diversity.  Protocol challenges were cryptographically chained so that timely responses could only be constructed if block retrieval was performed in parallel from multiple physical storage devices. To account for the heterogeneous storage and network conditions,  loose bounds on processing (seek, read, and compute) delay and network latency were introduced. These bounds reflect the limitations of existing technologies and can be adjusted to any future technology updates. 
The project further considered privacy issues related to remote file storage.

The PIs studied private information retrieval (PIR) methods which allow users to retrieve data from remote databases without revealing the identity of that data. Prevailing approaches that achieve perfect privacy incur a prohibitive communication cost when files are stored on a single database. The PIs investigated practical aspects of PIR by introducing weaker forms of privacy that trade communication efficiency for privacy. Specifically, the PIs introduced the notion of Asymmetric Leaky PIR (AL-PIR) where some information about the identity of the desired message is allowed to leak to the databases, and some information about the undesired messages stored in the database is allowed to leak to the user. Further, the privacy model of latent variable PIR (LV-PIR) was investigated. In this model, the goal is to reliably retrieve desired information from a public database without leaking any information about a latent (hidden) variable/attribute. A compelling use case of LV-PIR is accessing an online service to obtain information (e.g., news articles, movies, etc.) without revealing the user’s political ideology, religious affiliation, sensitive health information, etc. For both privacy models, fundamental capacity bounds were derived and new schemes were designed that satisfy the AL-PIR and LV-PIR properties.

The PIs further investigated the problem of file placement and user association in storage-limited mobile edge computing (MEC) systems, where multiple edge nodes (ENs) collaborate on servicing a pool of clients. Formulating the problem as a sequential decision-making problem, the solution for a single EN was initially derived by transforming the formulation into a multi-armed bandit (MAB) problem and solving it via a Thompson sampling (TS) algorithm. A novel solution framework for the multi-EN scenario was subsequently developed which led to a significant reduction in average latency compared to the state-of-the-art. 

The project fulfilled several educational and outreach objectives. It provided opportunities for training and professional development to several Ph.D. and M.S. students (two of the students were females). One student supported in part by this project joined academia as a research assistant professor. The rest of the students have assumed positions in leading industry companies. Moreover, results from this project have been integrated into the curricula of undergraduate and graduate courses. 

The project has resulted in five Ph.D. dissertations (one in progress) and over 25 peer-reviewed publications in top international conferences and high-impact journals. The project results have been broadly disseminated through these publications and also via numerous presentations at conferences, research colloquia, and university seminars.
